Socialist Republic of Viet Nam: Preparing the River 
Basin Water Resources Management and 
Development Project 
 
 
 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Justification 
1.  The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  has  requested  financing  by  ADB  and  an  (as  yet 
unidentified) cofinancier for a project to prepare for future national water security by establishing 
a national water resources information system (WRIS) that will enable fact-based integrated 
water resources management, including a rational policy-based system for water allocation and 
demand  management. The  Ministry  of  Natural  Resources  and  Environment  (MoNRE)  was 
assigned the responsibility in 2008 for the collection and management of natural resources and 
environmental data. A revised Law on Water Resources further strengthened this position. ADB 
will provide project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) to assist the government to prepare 
a project for ADB processing, including independent assessment of policy and technical issues 
and their institutional ramifications. The PPTA is to assist the government define the scope, 
cost,  financing  plan,  implementation  arrangements  including  assigning  responsibility  for 
advance action. It will assess capacity building needs within MoNRE and custodians of related 
databases and define post-project O&M arrangements. Safeguard and financial management 
policies  of  both  the  ADB  and  the  government  that  should  be  followed  during  project 
implementation will be defined. The PPTA will guide on actions to maximize the social and 
economic benefits, including the formulation of water allocation procedures, data sharing and 
access protocols to improve long-term sustainable management of natural resources and the 
environment; the planning of training required to encourage inter-agency data sharing; assured 
access to summary data and findings by the general public, and the setting of transparent 
charges for the sale of information generated from the data. The PPTA will advise on the need 
and scope of a phased implementation of the proposed system of data gathering, analysis and 
management, and for the introduction of a basin approach to water management. The PPTA will 
define the context for an assessment of the nation’s water governance, as a means to assess 
the effort required or the likelihood to achieve lasting change for the purpose of water security.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement 
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000 equivalent, of which $700,000 equivalent will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF).  The 
government will finance the remaining $200,000 equivalent, primarily in kind. The TA will be 
administered by ADB. The government has been informed that approval of the TA does not 
commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. The detailed cost estimate is shown in Table A4.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  A total of 48 person-months of consulting services (consisting of 16 person-months of 
international  and  32  person-months  of  national  expertise)  will  be  required  for  project 
preparation. The consulting services will be recruited from a firm selected using QCBS method 
at  a  ratio  of  80:20  based  on  a  full  technical  proposal.  A  summary  of  the  consultancy 
requirements is shown in Table A4.3. The international Database Specialist will be the team 
leader. The outline terms of references for the international consultants are described below.

5.  Team  Leader/  Water  Resources  Information  Specialist  (international,  5  person-
months). Qualifications: 15 years experience designing, installing and operating data collection 
networks for hydro-meteorological data and surface- and ground-water characteristics, including 
quantitative  and  qualitative  attributes.  Previous  experience  in  project  preparation  for  inter-
national development agencies is essential. Responsibilities: manage PPTA implementation; 
technical  oversight  and  guidance;  prepare  inception  and  final  reports;1  and  liaise  with  the 
government and ADB. Manage technical team of international and national specialists in various 
professional fields including hydrology, hydrologic network design, water quality, groundwater, 
information technology, GIS/mapping and institutional/legal aspects. The Team Leader / Water 
Resources  Information  Specialist  will  be  supported  by  and  complemented  by  the  national 
Deputy Team Leader / Water Resources Planning Specialist in both his team management and 
technical responsibilities. Further technical support on water resources data needs, availability 
and interpretation will be provided by the national Hydrologist / Hydro-meteorologist, the Water 
Quality Specialist, the Groundwater specialist and the Environment Specialist. The generic 
duties of the Deputy Team Leader will be to ensure and enable the unfettered access to data at 
national and provincial level.  
 
6.  Institutional,  Policy,  and  Legal  Specialist  (international,  4  person-months). 
Qualifications: 15 years experience in formulation of legal and institutional arrangements for the 
data management, including not less than 5 years in developing countries. Previous experience 
in  project  preparation  for  international  development  agencies  is  essential.  Responsibilities: 
review legal and institutional provisions in relation to MoNRE’s lead role as manager of Viet 
Nam’s water data; prepare draft protocols for data transfers between agencies (covering cost 
sharing and charges for the use of data); assist in formulation of data custodial rights and 
responsibilities;  review  legal  provisions  for  water  extraction  and  discharges  under  current 
legislation. Draft outline of national policy for water security through demand management. The 
international Institutional, Policy and Legal specialist will be assisted by and will guide the

7.  Database Specialist / Hydrographer (international 3 person-months). Qualifications: 15 
years experience in the design and implementation of hydrological databases and networks of 
distributed databases, including relevant experience in developing countries. Responsibilities: 
review existing data collection networks; delineate logical and acceptable distribution of river 
and groundwater basins; assess outputs and outcomes of relevant studies and investments 
projects;  list  core  data  sets  to  constitute  a  first  priority  for  consistent,  nation-wide  data 
measurement;  rationalize  and  streamline  site  and  data  identifiers;  prepare  guidelines  for 
transferring data sets into national directory; design appropriate core data network (including 
new  automatic  data  loggers  and  the  upgrading  of  existing  recorders/transmitters).  The 
international Database Specialist / Hydrographer will collaborate with the national Hydrologist, 
the Groundwater specialist and the Water Quality Specialist on the structure and mechanisms 
for integration of the respective distributed databases. 
 
8.  Information Technology Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). Qualifications: 
10 years experience in specifying and commissioning computer hardware and software to 
support  data  management  for  water  resources  and  socio-economic  attributes,  including 
experience  in  developing  countries.  Previous  experience  optimizing  distributed  database 
systems  is  essential.  Responsibilities:  review  and  assess  existing  computer  hardware  and 
software systems within MoNRE and its partner agencies; select appropriate data management 
systems based on future needs and staff capacity and experience within MoNRE and other 
agencies  involved;  design  approach  for  the  integration  of  existing  data  into  any  new 
database(s);2 and provide operational training to government staff. The international Information 
Technology Specialist will be supported by a national Information Technology Specialist, who 
will be instrumental in conducting the detailed assessments of existing databases, staff needs 
and capacity, and in the actual delivery of relevant training. 
 
9.  GIS/ Mapping Specialist (international, 1.5 person-months). Qualifications: 10 years 
experience in developing GIS to support the storage, retrieval and processing of geo-referenced 
data,  including  not  less  than  2  years  experience  in  developing  countries.  Responsibilities: 
review and assess existing map-based information systems for water resources and related 
environmental  and  socio-economic  data  within  MoNRE  and  its  partner  agencies;  select 
appropriate GIS software and systems to incorporate or convert existing data files; formulate a 
structure for presentation of an inventory of water and related natural resources for all of major 
fresh water basins; provide operational training to government staff in GIS utilization. The 
international GIS / Mapping Specialist will be supported by a national GIS / Mapping Specialist.  
 
10.  Social Safeguard Specialist (international, 1.0 person-month). Qualifications: 10 years 
experience  in  analyzing  social  and  gender  issues  for  international  development  projects, 
preferably in Southeast Asia; familiarity with ADB’s social safeguards and gender development 
requirements. Responsibilities: assess the design of the project within the context of social,  
gender  issues,  and  indigenous  peoples’  concerns;  ensure  that  appropriate  resettlement 
safeguard measures are incorporated, which includes elements that promote enhanced social 
welfare; conduct socioeconomic and gender analyses and prepare stakeholder participation 
plan,  gender  action  plan  and  ethnic  minorities  development  plan  where  relevant.  The 
international Social Safeguard Specialist will be assisted by and guide the work done by the 
national Social Development and Gender Specialist, who will more specifically conduct a gender

and capacity) of MONRE and other relevant agencies that will be responsible for the O&M of the 
WRIS, in coordination with institutional, policy and legal specialist. The national specialist will 
assess to what extent the current statistics include sex-disaggregated or gender perspectives 
and opportunities; conduct an assessment of the potential for stakeholders’ participation in 
water  governance;  and  develop  a  Resettlement  Framework  in  response  to  likely  potential 
resettlement issues. The two social specialists shall assist MoNRE with the preparation of 
appropriate safeguard documents, consistent with national and ADB safeguard requirements. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  The executing agency will be MoNRE which will set up a CPMU to supervise the PPTA 
implementation. Procurement will be done in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Disbursements will be done in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). In-
kind contributions to be provided by the executing agency will include office space, counterpart 
staff,  office  staff  and  translators,  domestic  transport  and  basic  office  and  communications 
equipment. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is given in Table A4.4.
